loans.use: to pay for products for the shop

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past year, she has operated a food stall business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of delayed payments by those who purchase goods on credit. Saumu dreams of establishing a café business in the future. 

With the loan of Kshs 40,000, she wants to purchase food stock, bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase food stock, bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna is a 38 year-old mother who is blessed with 2 children. She has a retail shop where she sells dry goods, like pants, t-shirts, blouses, jackets, underwear and skirts. She has been in this business for almost 4 years. 

Lorna is asking for a loan of PHP 25,000 to purchase additional goods to sell, like pants, t-shirts, blouses and jackets. Each month, Lorna earns about PHP 8,000 by selling different kinds of clothes.

In the future, Lorna hopes to strengthen this kind of business in order to supplement the income of her husband.  She will use it for tuition fees and allowances for their children. She hopes that someday, through the continuous support and assistance of the Kiva lenders, her business will grow and their children will finish their studies.

loans.use: to purchase additional dry goods to sell, like pants, T-shirts, blouses and jackets

loans.name: Ana Del Socorro

texts.es: Ana Del Socorro tiene 54 años, su esposo le ayuda con el negocio su negocio es la venta de mercadería en general. Tiene 2 hijos pero solamente 1 está a su cargo. Comenzó hace 36 años atrás cuando aprendió la actividad como vendedora en un tramo del mercado fue así que logro obtener sus propios ingresos y mejorar cada día el inventario y tener su negocio. Labora todos los días desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 9 de la noche. Con la ayuda del préstamo desea comprar bolsos, calzado, toallas, sabanas, manteles, lápiz labial y otros.
texts.en: Ana Del Socorro is 54 years old.  Her husband helps her with her business selling general merchandise.  She has two children but only one is in her care.  She started working 36 years ago as a saleswoman on a stall in the market.  In this way, she managed to make her own income, continually improve her stock and keep her business running.  She works every day, from 7.00am to 9.00pm.  With the help of this loan, she would like to buy bags, footwear, towels, sheets, tablecloths, lipsticks, etc.

loans.use: to buy bags, footwear, towels, sheets, tablecloths, lipsticks, etc.

loans.name: Oscar Alonso

texts.es:
Oscar aprendió a reparar electrodomésticos desde muy joven ya que su familia se ha dedicado a esta labor y es así como su padre pudo sacarlos adelante.

El señor Oscar quiere ampliar su negocio para así poder continuar pagándole a sus hijos los estudios universitarios y para esto necesita mantener repuestos para todo tipo de electrodomésticos y así poder ofrecerle mayor rapidez a sus clientes en la reparación de los mismos.
texts.en:
Oscar learned to repair domestic appliances when he was very young since his family worked in the trade and his father was able to support them through his work.

Oscar wants to expand his business so he can afford to pay for a college education for his children.  To do this he must stock repair parts for every type of appliance so he can offer a quick repair service to his customers.

loans.use: To buy repair parts.

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.es:
Trinidad  de 58 años de edad, vive con su familia en su casa propia, no cuenta con los servicios básicos, ubicada en la zona rural del distrito de Tambogrande, la cual pertenece al departamento de Piura.  Esta zona se caracteriza por la actividad agrícola, ganadera y artesana.

Desde hace algunos años Trinidad se dedica la venta de productos de primera necesidad (leche, arroz, aceite, azúcar, papel higiénico, atún, etc) y de bebidas, su negocio lo a colocado en su misma casa para su comodidad y seguridad, con las ganancias que obtenga por la venta de sus productos  trata de cubrir  todos sus gastos y mejorar el nivel de vida de su familia.

Para poder  implementar su negocio a solicitado un crédito a Edpyme Alternativa  de 2000 nuevos soles para comprar más mercadería con la intensión de surtir su tienda, con el único ideal de que su negocio crezca y tenga los productos necesarios para ofrecer a sus clientes.  Trinidad es una persona responsable y trabajadora que se preocupa por brindarles más comodidades a sus hijos y otras oportunidades en un futuro.
texts.en:
Trinidad, 58, lives with his family in his own home.  He does not have basic amenities and is located in a rural area in the Tambo Grande district, in Piura department. This area is characterized by agriculture, cattle raising and handicrafts.

For several years Trinidad has sold basic supplies (milk, rice, oil, sugar, toilet paper, tuna, etc.) and beverages. He has operated his business from his own home for convenience and security. He tries, with the profits obtained from the sale of his products, to cover all of his expenses and to raise his family’s standard of living.

In order to help his business he has requested a loan of 2,000 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa, so that he can buy more merchandise to stock his store. His goal is to see his business grow and to have the necessary items to offer his customers.

Trinidad is a responsible, dedicated and hardworking person who is concerned about providing more advantages and future opportunities to his children.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise to stock his store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy merchandise.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a focused businessman who is 34 years old. He is married and blessed with two children. For the last five years, he has been managing a van (matatu) transport service to earn a living. He also runs a grocery store for more income. In the next five years, he wants to buy three vans. He is requesting a loan of 25,000 Kenyan shillings to service his van.

loans.use: To service his van

loans.name: Mónica Patricia

texts.es:
La Señora. Mónica es socia del banco comunal El Cruce hacia el Futuro, vive por la parroquia de Sinincay, este lugar cuenta con una gran belleza natural y su gente es muy hospitalaria, su gastronomía es muy variada y  su gente se dedica al comercio, cría de animales y a la agricultura. 

Doña Mónica tiene 35 años, es separada pero en su unión conyugal ha concebido una hija de 13 años de edad que estudia en un colegio de la ciudad. No tiene casa propia por lo que vive en casa de su mamá con quien comparte los gastos del hogar.
 
Nuestra socia labora como empleada privada de domingo a domingo en horarios rotativos.
 
En el banco comunal se encuentra hace un año y medio y su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de víveres para su hogar.
 
Su sueño es comprarse un vehículo.
texts.en:
Mónica is a member of the 'El Cruce hacia el Futuro' community bank.  She lives in Sinincay parish which has great natural beauty.  Its people are very hospitable.  The local cuisine is very varied and the people work in commerce, raise animals and farm.

Mónica is 35 years old.  She is separated but she has a 13-year-old daughter from her marriage.  Her daughter attends school in the city.  Mónica does not own her own home and so lives in her mom's house, sharing the household expenses.

Mónica works as a private employee from Sunday to Sunday.  She works shifts.  She has been a member of her community bank for one and a half years and she will invest her new loan in buying provisions for her household.

Her dream is to buy a vehicle.

loans.use: to buy provisions

loans.name: Saulo

texts.en:
Saulo is 35 years old and lives in the town of Matuga in the Luweero region of Uganda. He is married and has 3 children; 2 are currently in school. For the past 10 years, Saulo has been working hard to manage his grocery store, which sells processed and unprocessed food items. 

To help expand his business, Saulo has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more maize and rice for resale, and will help Saulo to generate greater profits and improve the standards of living for his family. Saulo hopes that in the future he will be able to get contracts with school programs and to become the largest supplier of products like flour in all of Matuga. 

Saulo is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Saulo who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more maize and rice for resale

loans.name: Catalina

texts.es: Catalina,de 40 años de edad,y tiene 6 hijos,ella se dedica a la venta de ropa variada para caballeros y damas,como playeras,pantalones,etc ella lleba 10 años de dedicarse a esta actividad,y poco a poco se ha superado en su negocio,ella nos cuenta que esta muy contenta porque sus clientes han aumentado considerablemente,esta solicitando este credito para la compra de ropa variada ya que sus clientes le piden otros diseños y no alcanza surtirles,el sueño de ella es tener un puesto mas grande y darles lo mejor a sus hijos,para que en un futuro tengan mejores oportunidades.ella espera que la fundacion le pueda ayudar con el credito que ella esta solicitando.
texts.en:
Catalina, 40, has 6 children and works selling clothing for men and women like t shirts, pants, etc. She has 10 years of experience doing this and little by little has overcome challenges in her business. She tells us that she is very happy because her customers have increased considerably. 

She is asking for this loan to buy varied clothing because her customers are asking for other designs and she can't supply them. Her dream is to have a bigger stall and to give the best to her children so that in the future they have better opportunities. She hopes that the foundation can help her with the loan she is requesting.

loans.use: to buy varied clothing to sell.

loans.name: Nyamdavaa

texts.en:
Nyamdavaa is 35 years old and the father of three children. He lives with his wife and three children in Mongolian nomadic tent on his own land which he recently purchased. He is a very honest and helpful person. He has been servicing cars for more than 15 years. He has plenty of experience in this sector. His car service shop is located in a very busy street, thus it is more profitable.
 
He is seeking to buy old cars and fix them to sell them at higher prices. He is requesting a loan to purchase old cars to start his new business.

loans.use: To purchase old cars to start his new business.

loans.name: Akkiz's Group

texts.en:
Akkiz is the leader of this group. She is 45 and married to a constructor who works in Russia. Akkiz takes care of four children: two sons and two daughters. The older son is employed and the other children are students.  Each month the husband transfers Akkiz some money to meet the family needs. Akkiz herself works as a schoolteacher. In order to earn additional money, she breeds livestock. Selling the dairy products, she earns an additional 2,000 soms to meet their needs. With money received from the loan she plans to purchase a sheep for breeding. Some part of the loan she will spend for house repairing. In the future, Akkiz wishes to open a bakery in the center of her village, she explains that there are no bakeries in their village.

Where Did This Loan Come From? 

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a sheep and repair the house.

loans.name: Felicidad

texts.en:
This is Felicidad. She is 63 years old and a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. Her husband is Apolonio, a mason and a father to her two children. She, together with her husband and children, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Felicidad operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a small amount of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Aside from this she also sells cooked viand, a traditional Filipino dish, in her store. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 17,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Felicidad hopes her business will grow in the coming years and dreams of giving her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration through the study of the Word of God.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Cremilde

texts.pt:
Nasceu na Província de Inhambane, Sul de Moçambique, solteira e mãe de 1  filho ainda bebé. Fez o nivel secundário e parou por falta de condições financeiras pela parte dos pais. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e não sustenta mais ninguem. 

Saiu de Inhambane para o Distrito de Boane a procura de emprego, é recepcionista ha mais de 5 anos na Ara Sul e tem um salario de 5.037.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e poupa algum na sua conta bancaria(BIM).
Nunca teve emprestimos noutros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku atravez de uma amigo que tambem é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu primeiro emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 24.000.00mt, com qual pretende comprar material de construção para dar continuidade a obra da sua casa(barrotes, chapas, cimento, pedra,  e outros).
Compromete se a pagar devidamente e no futuro pretende terminar a obra da sua casa e mobiliar, para tal tenciona solicitar mais emprestimos a Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Cremilde was born in the Inhambane Province in southern Mozambique.  She is single and has one son who is still a baby.  She attended high school but did not finish because her parents did not have the financial resources.  She owns the home where she lives with her family and she doesn't support anyone else.  

Cremilde left Inhambane for the Boane district to look for work.  She has been a receptionist for more than 5 years at Ara Sul, and she has a monthly salary of 5.037.00mt which she uses for household expenses and savings in her bank account (BIM).

She has never had a loan with other banks.  She learned about Hluvuku through a friend who is also a client.  This is her first loan with Hluvuku, in the amount of 24.000.00mt, which she plans to use to purchase materials to continue construction on her home (beams, metal panels, stones, etc.).

She promises to make her payments on schedule.  In the future, she plans to complete construction and furnish her home, and she will request additional loans from Hluvuku for that purpose.

loans.use: to purchase materials to continue construction on her home (beams, metal panels, cement, stone, etc.)

loans.name: Mwichinga B Group

texts.en:
Benjamin is the facilitator of the Mwichinga B group. Benjamin and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Benjamin and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Benjamin takes care of eight children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Benjamin had a very good maize yield harvesting 16 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Benjamin was only able to harvest three bags of maize on one acre of land.

With income from his maize sales, Benjamin will educate his children and save for future use.

In 2012, the members of Mwichinga B group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

The photograph shows Benjamin with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Leydi Yamileth

texts.es:
Leydi, vive en compañía  de su esposo y su bebe de un año de edad, ella vende antojitos, aprendió por su madre ya que tiene experiencia en el negocio, el horario es variado ya que a veces termina rápido de su venta.
Ella solicita un préstamo para la compra de materia prima para la elaboración de antojitos como: papas,  yuca, maíz y aceite, para continuar en su negocio y contar con todo lo necesario para la venta.
La aspiración de Leydi es que su negocio prevalezca y que le genere mayores ganancias, con esta inversión espera tener buenos resultados.
texts.en:
Leydi lives with her husband and one year old baby.  She sells snacks and learned to do this from her mother who has lots of business experience.  Her schedule varies and sometimes she completes her sales quickly.

She is asking for a loan to buy ingredients such as potatoes, yucca, corn, and cooking oil, to make her snacks, continue her business, and have everything she needs to make her sales.

Leydi’s aspiration is to have her business prevail and generate greater income.  She expects this investment to bring good results.

loans.use: to buy ingredients.

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en: Flordeliza is 41 years old, married and has four children who range in age from 9 to 19 years old. She earns a living by selling dried fish, vegetables and various food items she cooks herself. She earns about PHP 8,000 a month and is applying for this loan to buy more items to sell to her customers and a scale that she can use to weigh her goods. She earns about PHP 8,000 a month and hopes to have enough money to allow her children to stay in school through college and have bright futures.

loans.use: to buy a scale and food items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Doña Teresa de 55 años de edad trabaja en agricultura desde hace 30 años, tiene 7 hijos entre 15 a 36 años de edad, casada desde hace 35 años, vive en Monquecagua, Intibucá.
Ella cultiva papa, maíz, frijoles y también realiza otra actividad donde obtiene otros ingresos como la cría de gallinas. Esta actividad agrícola es una de las principales fuentes de ingresos de esa comunidad.
Ha logrado mejorar la producción con los préstamos que ha solicitado a ODEF, este préstamo de 11,000.00 es el cuarto préstamo y es para invertirlo en compra de semillas de papa, abonos y gastos de mantenimiento de sus cultivos. 
Doña Teresa es miembro del grupo solidario Primero de Mayo, el cual esta formado por 3 miembros mas.
Su plan y su sacrificio es seguir mejorando y ampliando la producción, para tener un mejor nivel de vida.
texts.en:
Teresa, 55, has been farming for 30 years.  She has 7 children between the ages of 15 and 36.  She’s been married for 35 years and lives in Monquecagua, Intibucá.  She grows potatoes, corn and beans and also earns money from an additional occupation: she raises chickens.  Farming is one of this community’s main sources of income.

She has managed to improve production with loans requested from ODEF.  This loan for 11,000.00 is the fourth one and it’s to buy potato seeds, manure and to pay crop maintenance costs.

Teresa is a member of the “Primero de Mayo” (May First) communal bank which has three other members.  Her plan and her sacrifice are to continue improving and expanding production to have a better standard of living.

loans.use: to buy potato seeds, manure and to pay crop maintenance costs.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
La socia Francisca; pertenece al banco comunal "SEÑOR DE LA AGONIA DE TARAY"; El banco se encuentra ubicado en el Distrito de Taray perteneciente a la Provincia de Pisac departamento de Cusco.

La socia tiene 43 años de edad y es casada, la socia tiene 4 hijos de los cuales dos son independientes; La socia se dedica a la compra y venta de artesania, ella vende sus trabjaos de arte en el mirador de Taray y su conyugue es carpintero y la socia cuando no esta vendiendo sus trabajos ya que le dan espacio solo dos dias de la semana para exhibir sus trabajos, la socia alterna sus actividades con el laqueado, y otros trabajos menores en la carpinteria de su esposo, la socia en esta ocasión desea invertir el prestamo en la compra de madera, clavos entre otros productos para realizar muebles y venderlos.

La socia agradece el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el tiempo establecido.
texts.en:
The member Francisca belongs to the communal bank Lord of the Agony of Taray. The communal bank is located in the district of Taray belonging to the province of Pisac in the department of Cusco.

The member is 43 years old and is married and has four children of which two are independent. 

The member works buying and selling crafts. She sells her works of art from the lookout point of Taray. Her husband is a carpenter. When the member is not selling her work, as she is given space only two days of the week to show her works, she alternates her work applying varnish, and other little chores involved with her husband’s work of carpentry. The member on this occasion wants to use the money from the loan to buy wood, nails and other products in order to make furniture to sell.

The member is thankful for the loan and she promises to make her payments according to the established schedule.

loans.use: to buy wood, nails and other products in order to make furniture to sell

loans.name: Karina

texts.es: Karina de 32 años de edad vive en la ciudad de Cartagena con su cónyuge y sus dos hijos en las edades de 5 y 7 años. Allí tiene una panadería donde  produce panes y postres, que vende  entre la gente del macroproyecto Ciudad Bicentenario, apoyado por la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo,  lugar  donde habita.  Ella había iniciado el negocio de tienda panadería, con su cónyuge en otro barrio, pero la ola invernal erosionó  su vivienda y perdieron recursos, así fue como fue reubicada con su familia en este megaproyecto.  Karina y su familia son personas de mucha persistencia, pues antes de emprender su tienda,  habían sido desplazados de su tierra en el departamento de Bolívar, posteriormente cuando estaban trabajando con firmeza, sobrevino la ola invernal , pero ellos no se dejan vencer por las adversidades y por eso en Ciudad bicentenario emprendieron su propia panadería, que aprovechando su anterior experiencia,  quieren darle un esquema de tienda donde adicionalmente vendan ranchos, víveres y artículos de la canasta familiar. Es su negocio el Marido de Karina prepara el pan y los postres y ella muy creativamente sale con su vitrina a la que le puso ruedas,  vendiendo por todo el mega barrio,  donde ahora habita. Ellos tienen muchos sueños de prosperidad, como el de adecuar un local independiente,  para el buen desempeño de su microempresa. Esta es la razón por la cual acuden a su credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará artículos de consumo que se venden en las tiendas, como víveres, carnes, abarrotes y materias primas en mayor volumen para elaborar nuevos productos de panadería, porque aun cuenta con su  horno, vitrinas cilindradoras y produce  panes y postres, los que reparte  en su vitrina rodante .
texts.en:
Karina, 32, lives in the city of Cartagena with her spouse and two children who are 5 and 7 years old.  She has a bakery there where she produces bread and pastries that she sells among the residents of Ciudad Bicentenario Macroproject which is supported by Fundación Mario Santo Domingo and is where she lives.

She had started the bakery business with her spouse in a different neighborhood but the winter surf eroded her house and they lost their resources which is how the family came to be relocated to this mega project.  Karina and her family are very persistent people because before starting her store they had been displaced from their land in Bolívar Department and then when they had succeeded in working steadily the winter surf came.   But they don’t let themselves be defeated by adversity and that’s why they started their own bakery in Ciudad Bicentenario which availing themselves of their prior experience they want to transform  into a store where they will also sell snacks, foodstuffs and basic staple items.

In her business, Karina’s husband prepares the bread and desserts and she very creatively goes out with her display case that she attached wheels to selling throughout the mega neighborhood where she now lives.

They have many dreams of prosperity like setting up a stand-alone locale to better develop their micro business.  This is why they are calling on their Kiva loan, their first financing from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo that will be used to buy merchandise sold in stores like foodstuffs, meat, groceries as well as ingredients for bakery items in large volume because she still has her oven, cylindrical display cases and still makes bread and desserts that she sells from her rolling display case.

loans.use: to buy merchandise sold in stores like foodstuffs, meat, groceries as well as ingredients for bakery items in large volume.

loans.name: Benkadi  6 Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  Benkadi  6 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans, 5 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles traditionnelles à  Djigonso, un des villages de San, 4ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
Les spéculations cultivées sont : le riz et soja avec    SETOU,  1 ere debout en écharpe jaune  sur la photo.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, des semences, des petits matériels agricoles et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir : 1 hectare. 
La production sera vendue au niveau du village et au marché de San, après la récolte, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 170.000FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The members of the group "Benkadi 6" are married women averaging 36 years of age and five children each all living in traditional families in Djigonso, a village in San (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali) The women are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their farm work during the rainy season. They are on their third loan with the institution. The past loans have indeed been paid back. 

The crops grown are rice and soybeans, as is the case with SETOU, the first one standing and wearing a yellow scarf in the photo. With her loan, she intends to buy farm inputs, some seeds, and sundry farm equipment and to cover the cost of plowing for maintaining one hectare.

The produce will be sold in the village and at the San market after the harvest. The customer base is composed of men and women. 

She expects to make an average profit of 170,000 francs CFA per planting season. This profit will enable her to repay her loan and also to help her husband to cover day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: to cover the cost of plowing and to buy farm inputs, sundry equipment, and some seeds

loans.name: Yecenia Del Carmen

texts.es:
Yecenia, mayor de edad casada y con 4 hijos, originario de Montería, es una mujer muy trabajadora.
Se caracteriza por ser una persona responsable, también con muchos deseos de superación personal.

Desea iniciar un negocio de miscelánea con la cual planea obtener los recursos necesarios para la manutención de su familia.

Es por esta razón que solicita un apoyo económico para la compra de una vitrina y mercancía como cosméticos, ropa, calzado, artículos para el hogar, entre otros,

Apoyando este nuevo proyecto estarás contribuyendo al desarrollo de las mujeres colombianas.

loans.use: compra de una vitrina y mercancía como cosméticos, ropa, calzado, artículos para el hogar, entre otros,

loans.name: Ibrahima

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by four entrepreneurs hailing from the island village of Cachuouane in southern Senegal.  Their representative, Ibrahima T., submitted the following business proposal:  

 

“The group ‘Assoukatene’ is made up of four men who are all traditional fishermen and who have decided to work in collaboration.  The group wishes to purchase nets and rowing pirogues (the handmade wooden canoes of Senegal).  The group will be divided into two teams of two fishermen who will undertake all types of fishing in order to provide the local population with fish, throughout every season of the year.  We will be able to repay the loan without problems in a matter of months after we begin these activities.”  

 

Note from CRESP: The attached photo depicts traditional pirogues and fishermen in the Casamance River, however the individuals in the photo are NOT from the Assoukatene group.  We will update this entry with pictures of Ibrahima and his associates as soon as possible. 

 

Background

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group.  Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, which provide the rural poor throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities.  Repayment rates within these groups are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members.  However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income.  This has prevented the traditional associations from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities.  Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance (SEM) works with our partner organization CRESP to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Canoe and fishing net purchase

loans.name: Bakhsheish

texts.en: Bakhsheish is IDP from armenian occupied district of Lachin since 1993. In 1999 he started his trading business in Baku city. in 2000-2006 he borrowed five loans from Normicro Baku branch amounting 1800$ in total and expanded in merchandise opportunity. Now he wants to borrow 1000$ to buy a variety of goods.

loans.use: To buy more bottles in cash

loans.name: Akenese

texts.en: Akenese lives in the Samoan village of Tafitoala.  She is 51 years old and has raised ten children.  A previous SPBD loan helped Akenese expand her cattle farm, and the business income is now able to provide for the basic needs of her large family.  Her husband and children all take part in the farm work and help Akenese pour water and cut grass for the animals.  Akenese has been delighted with the recent growth in her cattle farm and is enthusiastic about investing further.  She is seeking a loan to buy equipment for her farm, such as fencing materials, bush knives, gloves, etc.

loans.use: Purchase of fencing, knives, gloves

loans.name: Ramatu

texts.en: Ramatu runs a small kiosk at her residence in Makeni Town.  As a petty trader, she sells soft drinks and some small food items.  Before her first loan she had a very limited variety of drinks and thus had few customers.  After the previous loan, the thirty one year old Ramatu expanded her business and has acquired more customers as a result.  She uses the profit to assist her husband in paying the family expenses. while she saves to repay her loan.  Ramatu feels a strong sense responsibility and is determined to further develop her business.

loans.use: Purchase inventory for her small drink kiosk

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys Avelina A. Carballo works in her house as a hair stylist. She offers a variety of hair services: perms, hair coloring, cuts, blow-drying, and highlights. She has fewer clients in the winter, but during the summer, she has many clients each day. For example, now in the winter, she sees about 5 customers per day.

Gladys, 37, is the mother of three children, aged 18, 11 and 2. She began her business in her house 10 years ago, but started working at age 17 with her mother. Gladys is currently constructing a new building that costs her US$1600. It is located in front of her house, and she plans to move her current working area into the new building where she will place her new salon and also a small snack store. She wants to sell fast food and drinks, such as empanadas, milanesa, and sandwiches.

She is very happy that her business has been successful enough that she can expand further. With her loan, she wants to finish the construction of the salon and her small food shop. She also needs to install security bars in order to prevent robberies.

loans.use: To finish construction of a new hair salon.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increase his stock

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca is a member of the lending group, Nyame Beba of Elmina. These group members guarantee loans through a group repayment pledge. Peer support provides the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount. The five members of this group have known each other for many years and provide a lot of support for each other as they all work inside the Elmina market.

Francisca owns a small general store. She sells a variety of goods used in Ghanaian dishes. Francisca has been purchasing much of her stock on credit, paying her supplier back after she has sold the products. This allows Francisca to purchase a lot of goods with the little capital she has; however, buying stock this way generates very little profit, as most of the profit goes to her distributor. With her loan, she hopes to buy tomatoes, onions, oil, and her other stock in bulk, so she can make more profit.

Francisca is currently supporting her four children through school. Two of her children are in middle school and two are in elementary school.

loans.use: Increase her capital so that she can stop buying on credit and get more profit to sustain her business.

loans.name: Naome's Group

texts.en:
Naome K. is a 56 year old mother of 7 children (ages 25, 24, 22, 29, 27,9, 7) who operates a retail shop. She wants the loan to begin cash crop farming and start a business for her sons.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To begin cash crop farming

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Mambo from Mwanza, Tanzania! This is 34-year-old Stella M.. She is married with two children, ages 12 and 14. In 2000 Stella established a grain business and now requires a loan of $450 in order to purchase additional stock of rice, maize, and beans in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA has taken a leading role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment—a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of rice, maize, and beans in bulk.

loans.name: Saron

texts.en:
Mrs. Saron D. and her husband have been married since 1979. They have five children; three sons and two daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home, while the other three (one of whom is working in Phnom Penh) live at home. The family live on an island in the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. D. has been a silk weaver since 1979. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. Two of her children that live at home also weave. Her husband is farming and raising cows.

She is requesting a second loan of $350. This money will be used to purchase silk materials, sewing thread and fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use:
To purchase silk materials, sewing thread and fees for 
selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.name: Isabel's Group

texts.es:
Miriam and Isabel have been members of the Communal Bank Ayllu, which means "Family" in Quechua for one and two years respectively. As members of the bank they have learned to save, to be responsible and punctual.

Miriam is 22 years old and is a single mother to a one year old boy. She sells Salchipollo (French fries with chicken) at the entrance of her house. She also tends to a small grocery store she's had for about a year and that is growing little by little.

Isabel, on the other hand, is 48 years old, married and has five children. She bakes breads traditional to the region, and sells them at the entrance of her house.

Maria and Isabel need loans in the amount of 1500 and 600 soles, which will be used to purchase sodas, milk, sugar, rice, flour and shortening. Their dreams are to have financial stability, improve their businesses and build their houses.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

Miriam e Isabel pertenecen al Banco Comunal Ayllu que significa “Familia” en quechua hace 1, 2, años respectivamente. En su Banco Comunal aprendieron a ser responsables, puntuales y a ahorrar.

Miriam es madre soltera, tiene 22 años y 1 hijo, Miriam venD. salchipollo en la puerta D. su casa y hace 1 año tiene una tienda D. abarrotes que poco a poco esta creciendo.

Mientras que Isabel es casada, tiene 48 años y 5 hijos, Isabel elabora panes típicos D. la zona en su casa y lo venD. en la puerta D. su casa.

Miriam e Isabel necesitan préstamos D. 1500 soles y 600 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra D. gaseosas, leche, azúcar, arroz, harina y manteca. Los sueños D. Miriam e Isabel son tener estabilidad económica, mejorar sus negocios y construir su casa.

loans.use: To purchase sodas, milk, sugar, rice, flour and shortening.

loans.name: Zequentic 6 Group

texts.es:
Maria is 19 years old and since she was little, she has followed the tradition of her mother and sisters making and embroidering handicrafts. She has embroidered since she was little, and now makes shawls, table centerpieces, tablecloths, pillows, blouses, etc. She sells her merchandise in her community and to people who take it to San Cristobal to sell.

With the loan, she would like to buy raw materials (thread, fabric, and dyes). She is single and with the money she will help to contribute to household costs.

The other members of the group are Maria P. V., Juana Elena P. H., and Pascuala P. H. who are artisans.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer.

MARIA TIENE 19 AÑOS DE EDAD, COMO ES TRADICION DESDE QUE ES PEQUEÑA VE QUE SU MAMA Y SUS HERMANAS SE DEDICAN A LA ELABORACION DE ARTESANIAS, ELLA DESDE PEQUEÑA BORDA, ACTUALMENTE ELABORA REBOSOS, CENTROS DE MESA, MANTELES, ALMOADAS, BLUSAS, ETC, SU MERCANCIA ES VENDIDA EN SU COMUNIDAD Y A PERSONAS QUE SE ENCARGAN DE LLEVARLA A SAN CRISTOBAL CON SU CREDITO DECEA COMPRAR MATERIA PRIMA(HILOS, TELA Y TINTAS), ES SOLTERA Y EL DINERO EN SU MAYOR PARTE ES DESTINADO A LOS GASTOS FAMILIARES, LAS OTRAS INTEGRANTES DEL GRUPO SON: MARIA PÉREZ V., JUANA ELENA PÉREZ H. Y PASCUALA PÉREZ H. SON ARTESANAS.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials (thread, fabric, and dyes)

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es:
Pedro is 39 years old and has a minibus with which he works as part of the 10th of February Union in his community. His family is made up of his three children, his two parents and his wife, who is a homemaker. His family lives in a two room wooden house with no fence around it. Pedro's minibus has the capacity to transport 12 people. As he is a member of the union his routes are defined by them. He takes passengers to distant communities in the region. While he has years of experience in this field, competition is quite elevated because of the increase of public transport vehicles and unions that offer the same service. At the same time, demand has increased due to the growing migration of people from the interior. The following application is to repair his minibus, which does not have an exact price as he fix it and he will use the loan to buy parts. Previously he has obtained loans from the institution and demonstrated that he is a responsible person who is punctual with his loans.

Translated from Spanish by Aimee Sostowski, Kiva volunteer.

Pedro tiene 39 años de edad, tiene un minibus con el que trabaja en el Sindicato 10 de febrero de su localidad. Su familia esta conformada por sus tres hijos, sus dos padres y su esposa que realiza labores de casa. La familia vive en una casa de madera de 2 ambientes que no tiene barda. Pedro trabaja con su minibus que tiene capacidad de trasnporte para 12 personas, es socio del sindicato por lo que tiene rutas definidas por el mismo. Lleva pasajeros a las distintas comunidades de la zona. Su experiencia e este rubro es bastante larga, es por esta razón que si bien la competencia es elevada y sobre todo ahora por el incremento de vehiculos de transporte público y sindicatos que ofrecen el mismo servicio, paralelamente también creció la demanda por la creciente migración de personas del interior. La presente solicitud es para arreglar su minibus, no tiene el precio exacto ya que es él quien arreglará su minibus y el préstamo lo utilizará para comprar repuestos. Anteriormente ya obtuvo otros créditos en la institución y demostró ser una persona responsable y puntual en sus pagos.

loans.use: Repair of Mini Bus

loans.name: Josefa

texts.es:
Mrs. Josefa is 48 years old and lives in the suburb Villa Venezuela. She is married and has four children, two of whom live on their own and two who are still students. Her husband works in construction and contributes to the household expenses.

Mrs. Josefa has owned a business selling food for the past three years. She began the business with her own money and help from her husband. With this loan she wants to invest in the purchase of products such as rice, oil, and meat, in order to always be able to offer delicious and varied dishes to her customers. In the future, she would like to improve the quality of her service.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Josefa tiene 48 años de edad, habita en el barrio anexo Villa Venezuela, casada le tiene 4 hijos, dos de ellos son independientes y dos están estudiando, su esposo trabaja en la construcción y aporta a los gastos para el hogar.

El negocio de Doña Josefa. es venta de comida y lleva tres años de experiencia e inició con fondos propios y ayuda de su esposo, con el préstamo lo quiere para invertir en capital de trabajo en la compra de productos: arroz, aceite, carnes, para ofrecer siempre sus ricos variados platos a sus clientes. A futuro es mejorar la calidad del servicio.

loans.use: Purchase rice, meat, oil, and perishables to use in her dishes

loans.name: Aidha Namukasa's Group

texts.en:
Aidha N., 47 years old and single with six children, is the leader of a group of five women. Her eldest child is 28 and her youngest 15, and all are enrolled in school. Aidha lives in a suburban slum area outside of Kampala that is prone to flooding during the rainy season.

Aidha has been selling used footware for the past six years, buying from shops in Kampala and reselling them at one of the largest markets in Kampala, Owino Market. Working six days a week selling to both men and women, her busiest days are Mondays and Saturdays. The market for Aidha’s used shoes is good and she plans to use this loan to increase her stock.

Aidha has been working with MCDT for five years and has repaid over 10 loans. She originally decided to work with MCDT because she wanted to be able to help her family. Since then, the revenues from her business have helped her provide her children with good nutrition and pay school fees to ensure all her children get an education. Aidha one day hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

loans.use: To increase her stock of used shoes.

loans.name: Victoriosos Group

texts.es:
Mrs. Blanca Elena is the president of the communal bank “Victoriosos” and has her fabric business, and is a dynamic and enterprising person. The group is formed of 13 members. Blanca has three children and one of her objectives in asking for this loan is to improve her business to produce more. The members live in the Las Cabanas neighborhood, and thank Agrocapital for the opportunity to apply for this type of loan. The businesses to which they are dedicated include: selling fabrics, trinkets, furniture, tamales, macramé, Yanbal products, chocolate, clothing, food, furniture, and renting motorcycles. They aspire to grow their businesses to improve the quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva volunteer.

La sra. Blanca Elena es la presidenta de la banca comunal “VICTORIOSOS” tiene su negocio de tejidos, es una persona dinámica y emprendedora. El grupo está conformad@ por 13 soci@s. Blanca tiene tres hijos y uno de sus objetivos por los cuales solicitó este crédito es para mejorar su negocio y producir más. L@s soci@s viven en el Barrio Las Cabañas, agradecen a AGROCAPITAL por la oportunidad de acceder a este tipo de crédito. L@s beneficiad@s a los que se dedican son: ventas de tejidos, de golosinas, tamales, macrame, productos Yanbal, chocolate, abarrote, ropa de vestir, comida, muebles, alquilar motos. Todos tienen la aspiración de crecer en sus negocios para mejorar su calidad de vida.

loans.use: Capital de Operaciones

loans.name: Rachelle

texts.fr: Rachelle A. est revendeuse des produits d’alimentation générale à Wome, un village situé à environ 130 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Elle souhaite par ce crédit augmenter la capacité de son commerce en achetant des bidons d’huiles alimentaires de sacs de riz et des cartons de boîtes de conserves afin de mieux répondre aux besoins de la population.
texts.en:
Rachelle A. is a retailer of food in general in Wome, a village located about 130 km from Lomé, the Togolese capital. She would like to use this loan to increase the capacity of her business through the purchase of containers of cooking oil, sacks of rice, and boxes of canned food in order to respond to the needs of the population better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy drums of cooking oil, sacks of rice, and boxes of canned food

loans.name: Efrain

texts.es: El señor Efraín habita en el barrio Memorial Sandino, barrio ubicado en la capital de Managua, tiene la edad de 39 años, se encuentra casado con  la señora Fátima Dávila que tiene 30 años y es secretaria, ambos viven en casa propia y tienen un hijo de 7 años que esta estudiando. Actualmente el señor Efraín  se desempeña como oficial de la Policía Nacional, tiene 20 años dedicarse a esta profesión, el aspira seguir esforzándose para seguir contribuyendo a la seguridad del ciudadano y continuar sirviendo a su país, así mismo seguir mejorando las condiciones de vida de su familia, por tanto solicita un crédito de C$ 6,000 a un plazo de 9 meses, para la compra de cerámica y poder ponerle a su casa, ya que con los micro créditos que se le han  otorgado, el ha podido ir mejorando poco a poco su vivienda.
texts.en:
Efraín lives in the Memorial Sandino neighborhood, which is located in the capital of Managua. He is 39 years old and married to Fátima Dávila, who is 30 and is a secretary. They live in their own home and have a 7 year-old son who is a student. Efráin is currently an officer in the National Police, he has been in this profession for 20 years. He wants to keep working hard to make a contribution to the public´s safety and continue serving his country. He also wants to keep improving his family´s standard of living. For this, he is requesting a loan for C$6,000 over a period of 9 months, to buy tiles and install them in his house. With the microfinancing he has received he has been able to make improvements to his home bit by bit.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Install a tile floor in his home.

loans.name: Chanthoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthoeun V., 46, is a widow with one son who helps her with her silk weaving business. She has two siblings; one brother and her. Her brother has full-time employment. Besides her child she also has her elderly mother living with her as well. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Chanthoeun has been a silk weaver since 1980, a skill she learned from her parents when she was eighteen years old. Her mother has been a silk weaver since 1955, a skill she learned from her parents when she was fourteen years old as well. They sell their finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh.

Chanthoeun is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase construction materials for repairing her house.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials for repairing her house

loans.name: Thoeurn

texts.en:
Mr. Thoeurn T. lives in Kradas Khor village in Kampong Cham province.  He is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. 

On the plantation, he faces an obstacle because his field has infertile soil which has a bad effect on his crop.  In order to solve this problem, Mr. Thoeurn T. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field and make his crop more productive. 

He is a 58-year-old widower with two children, one of whom is a palm juice collector, while the other is a farmer who helps their father on the plantation.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support the field and make his crop more productive.

loans.name: Falefa

texts.en: Falefa K., 45, is married with 5 children.  She has 1 year of experience in the ice cake business. She sells to the villagers and general public 7 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~104 USD).  SPBD loans are Falefa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to purchase things for her business.

loans.use: Purchase sugar, cordial, plastic cups, and lollies.

loans.name: Kalsoom M. Iqbal Group

texts.en:
My name is Kalsoom and I am 46 years old. I have resided in a city named Borewala, Pakistan, for the past 37 years. My parents were not able to give me good education because of their little financial resources. I am married to a man whose name is M. I. and he has been a vegetable seller for the past 10 years. I am a mother of six kids: two sons and four daughters. My elder son works in a factory. Another reads in 4th standard. My elder daughter is married and she and her husband also live with us. My son-in-law has a spare parts selling business. My other daughters are getting education from a school which located near to the house.

I believe in hard work and I transfer this value to my kids also. I get up early and do household work, and then I help my husband in setting the vegetables on his cart. I have successfully repaid my first loan which I took from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I am applying again for a loan to buy spare parts to expand my son-in-law’s spare parts selling business.

I’m a group leader of some more women of my locality. Farzana firdous baji and Majidan baji each want a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Razia baji wants a loan to buy iron to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy spare parts to sell

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en: At the age of 33, Christopher D., married, with 3 children, lives in Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City, Southern Philippines. He strives to earn money for his family. Currently, he is engaged in the poultry business just like his brother. But the income from their poultry business cannot cope with the expenses they incur every day. That’s why he wants to open a  variety store business and is planning to ask for a loan from HSPFI amounting to PHP 11,000. The money will be  used to build a variety store  and purchase grocery items for re-sale. With this loan, he  may able to  send his children to school.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials for his variety store and grocery items for sale

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Marithza

texts.es:
La señora Marithza, pertenece al Banco Comunal “El Comercio”,  del distrito de Desaguadero, Provincia de Chucuito, Departamento de Puno, de 20 años de edad, de estado civil soltera, no tiene hijos, y posee estudios de secundaria completa.
Trabaja con el movimiento Manuela Ramos hace un año, ella se dedica a la venta de golosinas y galletas al mayor y productos variados (enseres de primera necesidad), su primer préstamo fue de 500 nuevos soles para mejorar su capital de trabajo.  
Ella desea solicitar un nuevo préstamo de S/. 1500.00 nuevos soles,por lo que se compromete en pagar en 03 cuotas mensuales,con dicho créditos lo invertiría para mantener su negocio y adquirir nuevos productos tales como: arroz en saco, fideos en bolsa, azúcar en bolsa, etc; los que serán distribuidos en el mercado local de Ilave, finalmente se compromete a pagar puntualmente su préstamo.
texts.en:
Marithza is a member of the Community Bank "El Comercio" of the Desaguadero District in the Province of Chucuito in Puno. She is 20 years old and she is single. She does not have any children and she completed high school.

She has been with the Manuela Ramos (Kiva Field Parnter) movement for the past year. She sells sweets and cookies wholesale and other varied products (primary needs items). Her first loan was for 500 nuevos soles and used it as working capital funds.

She requests a new loan of S/.1500 nuevos soles, which will be repaid in 3 monthly installments. With said loan, she will invest in the maintenance of her business and to acquire new products such as: sacks of rice, bags of pasta, bags of sugar, etc. These products will be sold in the market in Ilave. And finally, she promises to pay back her loan on time.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase new products such as rice, pasta, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
La señora Antonia Z. de Quintana es de la ciudad de Santanì. Ella tiene casa propia y tiene 42 años de edad. Antonia esta casada y tiene 2 hijos.

La cliente es comerciante y vende mercaderias de primera necesidad. Hace 10 años que trabaja en esta actividad y ya tiene formado una buena clientela gracias a los buenos precios de sus mercaderias. 

El cliente quiere comprar màs mercaderias ya que tiene muchos pedidos por parte de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Antonia Z. de Quintana lives in the City of Santanì. She is a home owner. She is 42 years old. She is married and has 2 children. She is a business woman. She sells basic products. She’s been working on this area for 10 years and she has a vast clientele thanks to the fair prices of the products she sells. She would like to buy more products as she has a lot of requests from her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de mercaderias

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: Maria tiene 24 años, es una joven que apoya mucho a sus padres, pues desea que su familia mejore económicamente. Su ganas de progresar la llevaron a dedicarse a la venta de comida, lo cual realiza dentro de su casa, cocina por las mañanas para tener todo listo al medio día, hora que sale a repartir los menús a sus pensionistas, que son más de 20 personas. Esta actividad no la realiza sola, pues cuenta con el apoyo de su madre, quien le enseña a preparar los diversos platillos para que sus clientes puedan sentirse satisfechos. Sin embargo, Maria desea seguir aprendiendo aun más de cocina, y tiene proyectado instalar en su hogar un pequeño restaurante, donde atienda junto a su madre, ya que la ventaja es que está ubicado en una avenida principal y tendrían gran concurrencia. María trabaja con MFP más de 3 años y le agrada pertenecer a un grupo tan ameno, pues las actividades y reuniones son muy favorables para compartir ideas y mejorar en su negocio. Los 1500 soles que solicita los usará en la compra de utensilios necesarios para iniciar poco a poco la instalación de su restaurante.
texts.en:
Maria is 24 years old, and is a young woman who gives a lot of support to her parents, as she desires that her family improve economically. Her desire to get ahead led her to work selling food, a job she undertakes from within the home. She cooks in the morning to have everything ready at noon, at which time she leaves to distribute the menus to her boarders (there are more than 20 of them). She does not do this work alone; she counts on her mother for support. Her mother teaches her how to prepare all the different dishes so that her clients are satisfied. However, Maria desires to keep learning more about cooking and has planned to install a small restaurant in her home, where she will work with her mother. They are located on a main avenue and would get a lot of business. Maria has worked with MFP for more than 3 years, and she enjoys belonging to such a pleasant group, as the activities and meetings are favorable for sharing ideas and improving business. The 1500 soles she is requesting will be used to buy the necessary utensils for starting to install the restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies for a future restaurant

loans.name: Sheila

texts.en:
Shiela D. is 33 years old, married and an expert at hair cutting and styling who runs a salon in Dolipos Bajo, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. Sheila is second of six children. Because she came from a big family, education for all of her siblings was impossible, but this has not discouraged her from pursuing her studies. Her interest in opening a salon allowed her to support herself doing home services for relatives, neighbors and professionals in their town. She also has a small space to accommodate walk-in customers.

Sheila fell in love with the programs and services of Paglaum MPC. The training, insurance and loans made possible by the cooperative are what she likes most, and she is a member of the group in good standing.  She has applied for a loan to buy additional hair products, and hopes to have a bigger space soon for her loyal customers and many new ones.

loans.use: To expand her beauty parlor and buy more supplies.

loans.name: Rec Infant-Hastings Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of the R.E.C. Primary School for Infants in Hastings requesting a group loan. The school was founded by the government to give pre-school education to the children of the Hastings community. There are currently 596 pupils and 13 staff.  Like many schools in Sierra Leone, R.E.C. Primary School for Infants lacks adequate classrooms, seating, and learning and teaching materials.

This will be the first loan for the teachers from SMT/Kiva. Because government salaries for teachers are usually very small, the SMT/Kiva loans are very much helpful to these teachers. With these loans, some of the teachers will invest in a side business to supplement their teaching salaries.  Others will use it to buy pieces of furniture like a bed or chairs, buy a piece of land on which to build a house, or purchase building materials.  Others will use the loan to pay for college fees to pursue further studies, or school fees for their children.  Gradually, with their monthly salaries, these teachers will repay their loans.

Gifty M. N. (fifth from right) is the deputy head teacher of the R.E.C. Primary School for Infants. She was born in Hastings, about twenty-three miles from Freetown, which is the capital city of Sierra Leone.  She is single with four children.  One of her children is already an adult, two are in secondary school, and one is still in primary school.  She has been a teacher for 31 years now.  Gifty will use this loan to buy home building materials – bundles of corrugated iron roofing, bags of cement, and sand.  This loan alone can not build her a house, but combined with her savings and subsequent loans she hopes to get from SMT/Kiva, she believes she will be able to build herself the house she so desires.  With a house, she will no longer be paying rent and will be a very happy woman together with her family.

loans.use: To buy home building materials.

loans.name: Bujinlham

texts.en: Bujinlham G. is 51 years old and lives with her husband in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her two sons have already grown up and live with their own families. Bujinlham has a small business retailing dairy products. She rents a small stall in the local food market and sells dairy products such as milk, cheese and other milk products. Since the start in 2003, her business has done well; her business capital has increased from 500,000 MNT to 2,500,000 MNT ($1 USD = 1,450 MNT). Her husband also helps in her business with purchasing and collecting dairy products from the wholesale market. In the future, she hopes to expand her business by adding more diverse products to her stall. With the profit, together with her husband, she has started building a house on the plot of land that they own. They are planning to finish building their house before year-end. She requests a loan to purchase more dairy products for her business.

loans.use: To buy more dairy products to increase her business inventory.

loans.name: Aisha Nakafeero's Group

texts.en:
Aisha is the leader of four members of a group. She is a 32 year widow with three children, aged between four and eight years old. All her children go to school. She lives and works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She resides in a rented one-room house where she stays with four people. Aisha doesn't take care of any additional family members. There is no electricity and piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day.

Aisha sell second-hand clothes in Kalerwe Market. She uses public transport to and from shopping in Kampala city twice a week. She sells to an average of ten people a day, to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. Her major monthly expenses include medication, rent for both accommodation and business, and feeding the family. She has been in this business for the last six years.

Aisha has been with MCDT for over seven years and this is her fourteenth loan. She's always worked with the same group-mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of clothes. Aisha aspires to see her business grow bigger and own a permanent business premise and home.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes.

loans.name: Nasreen Sarwar Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji lives in Borewala, Pakistan, a city which is famous for its shrines. She owns a two-room brick house which she has lived in with her family for 18 years. Her husband, S., runs a grocery store that is popular because of the owner's fariness and stock of quality items. Nasreen baji wants a loan to turn her husband’s grocery shop into full-fledged store.

This loan will also go to four other people: 
Parveen baji and Kubra baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their shops. 
Rani baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 
Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. 

This is a group loan. The funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible. 

Note: Nasreen baji is seated in the middle of the baji’s.

loans.use: To buy groceries for shop

loans.name: Mara Group

texts.en:
Rahma M., age 28, is single with one daughter who is three years old. She has a beauty salon that she started three years ago. She works from 10am to 7pm daily, and she is able to earn a monthly profit of about $113.

This will be Rahma’s third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to expand her salon and started selling clothes and bed sheets, which she sells from door to door. She has paid the loans back successfully. She now hopes for a new loan to expand both businesses.

Rahma will share this loan with her loan group, Mara, which totals 15 members. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Rahma is first on the right, back row, in a red t-shirt.

loans.use: To expand the salon and clothing sale businesses

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel F. is 56-years old farmer in Trento, Agusan del Sur. He is a father of only one child and dreamed of having more farms in the future to support his family. Currently, he has three hectares and all he wanted to do is make to flourish and  grow.

He owuld like to ask aloan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to buy fertilizers and other farming needs.

He likes CEVI services so much. Infact, he is now on his 7th loan. He likes CEVI because it has only 2% interest rate which is very low and very affordable to repay.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and other farming needs

loans.name: Mariana Mery

texts.es:
La señora Marina Mery  es socia del Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa de Lima”, del  distrito de Juli, provincia de Chucuito, departamento de Puno, ella tiene 30 años de edad,  es conviviente hace 5 años  y vive actualmente  con su pareja,  tiene 1 hijo, ella  estudio hasta concluir   superior completo.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace   un año, su primer préstamo fue de S/500.00 nuevos soles monto que le sirvió para adquirir mercadería para realizar productos de bordado en bayeta.

Actualmente, ella requiere un préstamo adicional S/ 700.00 nuevos soles con el préstamo ella podrá adquirir mas mercadería como bayeta, lanas de tal manera producir mas y las venderá en diferentes ferias de la región a veces entraga al por mayor es por ello que ella require mas capital. Ella manifiesta que vende de todo de acuerdo a la época en que estamos así como en tiempo escolar ella vende útiles escolares y así sucesivamente.

Su mayor sueño es conseguir un buen capital y tener su propio restaurante  y  conseguir trabajo como docente, que su hijo sea un buen  profesional para que no tengan problemas económicos en el futuro.

De las reuniones  le gusta los ahorros, sus ganancias, los temas educativos y compartir experiencias con las otras socias.
texts.en:
Sra. Mariana Mery is a member of the Communal Bank “Santa Rosa de Lima”, which is located in the District of Juli, Chucuito Province, Department of Puno. She is 30 years old and has been in a common law marriage for 5 years. She and her partner have 1 child. Sra. Mariana Mery completed her college education.

She has been working with Manuela Ramos for 1 year. Her first loan in the amount of 500 soles was used to purchase supplies for making embroidered fabrics.

At the moment, she is requesting another loan of 700 soles to buy more products, such as flannel and wool, so that she can produce more embroideries to sell at various regional fairs or through wholesale delivery since this requires additional capital. Sra. Mariana Mery tells us that she sells other products based on the time of the year. Since school has started, she sells items such as school supplies and other related merchandise.

Her biggest dream is to secure enough capital to open a restaurant or get a job as a teacher. She hopes that her child becomes a successful professional who does not have financial problems in the future. Sra. Mariana Mery enjoys her savings, earnings, the educational seminars provided by her Communal Bank, and sharing her experiences with other members.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase flannel & wool in different colors

loans.name: Dzogbavy

texts.fr: Cette femme est une spécialiste D. la vente D. tissus D. qualité et D. bijoux. Beaucoup D. clientes apprécient ses tissus et bijoux ; parce qu’elle se rend le plus souvent à Cotonou au Bénin où elle s’approvisionne en bijoux D. meilleure qualité. Elle a débuté ce commerce depuis 2002. Elle dispose d’une boutique qui lui appartienne et a même recruté une jeune fille qui l’aiD. dans son commerce. Cette boutique est située dans le quartier D. Hédzranawoé à Lomé. Elle sollicite en ce moment un crédit D. WAGES pour acheter des bijoux D. qualité. Elle est convaincue que ce crédit apportera plus D. splendeur dans ses activités.

loans.use: Achat de bijoux

loans.name: Idada

texts.en: A. is 49 years old and married with 7 children. She sells provisions and drinks. She is from Edo State, Nigeria. She is requesting for the loan amount of N80000 to purchase more drinks and provisions to sell. She thanks you for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Wilfredo Rene

texts.es: El sr. Wilfredo es cliente antiguo, trabajo desde año 2002 en el grupo solidario SANTIAGO FELIX en 12 secuencias, posteriormente solicito un credito individual y hasta la fecha se encuentra en 11 secuencia. El trabaja en la actividad de servicio de frenos de automovil hace 21 años y su esposa doña juana colabora con los gastos del hogar con la venta de lubricantes, tienen tres hijas que se encuentran en edad escolar y con los creditos y el trabajo que realizan adquirieron un terreno en la zona de pedregal donde estan construyendo poco a poco su vivienda . durante este tiempo demostraron responsabilidad en sus pagos
texts.en:
Mr. Wilfredo is an old customer; he has worked since 2002 in the group loan Santiago Felix for 12 loan cycles. Before he took out individual loans and is now in his 11th loan cycle. He works servicing automobile breaks for 21 years and his wife Mrs. Juana helps with the household expenses by selling lubricants. They have three daughters who are of school age and with the loans and work they acquired a lot in the pedregal zone where they are building little by little their home. During this time they have shown to be responsible with their payments.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy work materials.

loans.name: Donata

texts.es: Donata G. quiere construir un cuarto en la parte trasera de su vivienda por que donde vive esta muy reducida la sala-comedor y las recamaras es por ello que desea extenderse para vivir mas cómodamente. Su esposo esta en otra ciudad por que fue en busca de una oportunidad de trabajo y le manda dinero cada semana, Donata aparte de esos ingresos trabaja en un maquiladora como Auditora de calidad para así tener mas ingresos y dejarles un buen patrimonio a su familia.
texts.en:
Donata G. wants to add a room at the back of her house because her home has a livingroom/diningroom and bedrooms that are very small. For this reason she wants to add on to it in order to live more comfortably. Her husband is in another city because he went to look for a work, and he sends money every week. Donata earns income apart from this, working in a maquiladora as a quality control auditor, so that they can have more income and can generate more wealth for their family.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to build a room

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr: FAtoumata C. est une femme de 39 ans, elle est divorcée et vit avec ses deux enfants dont elle a la charge. Elle fait de la transformation et vente de pâte d'arachide, elle vend également de l'huile de palme. Les bénéfices générés par son petit commerce lui permettent de prendre en charge ses enfants.
texts.en:
Fatoumata C. is a 39-year-old divorcée who lives with her two children who she supports. She processes and sells peanut butter, and she also sells palm oil. The income generated by her small business allows her to take care of her children's needs.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To promote her business activity

loans.name: Pirmahmad

texts.ru: Пирмахмад Муродов проживает в районе Абдурахмони Чоми. Возраст 52 года. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Два старших сына находятся в России на заработках. Сам Пирмахмад более 7 лет занимается животноводством, он откармливает и продает скот. Кредит просит для закупа скота.
texts.en:
Pirmahmad M. lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi district. He is 52 years old, married and has 6 children. His two older sons currently work in Russia. Pirmahmad has been involved in animal husbandry for over 7 years. He raises and sells livestock. He is requesting a loan for the purchase of livestock.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Joke

texts.en:
Joke is 40 years old, is married and has 4 children. She is a member of a LAPO group and has been borrowing from LAPO for years. Joke sells books and provisions; she has been in this business for the past ten years. She is focused on making sure she meets the demands of her customers, which she says will also lead to an increase in profits for her.

Joke is asking for a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase books and provisions in bulk, as this will enable her to get a better discount and more profit on each sale. She promises to pay the loan back promptly and says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more books and provisions to sell

loans.name: Elvis Ricardo

texts.es: El Sr. Elvis A. T. vive en casa de sus suegros junto a su esposa en el caserío Santa Dominguita.Su esposa está embarazada, no tienen hijos. Cuentan con un pequeño terreno el cual han estado construyendo con mucho esfuerzo gracias a sus ahorros producto de su trabajo. Actualmente está laborando como obrero de planta en una empresa agroindustrial de la zona. Su esposa estuvo laborando pero por motivo de riesgo en su embarazo ha dejado de laborar. Sus suegros los apoyan con sus gastos ya que son jóvenes muy trabajadores. Su mayor sueño es terminar de construir su vivienda en la cual han invertido gran parte de sus ahorros. No cuentan con endeudamiento en ninguna institución financiera. La joven familia A. Carhuayo agradece el apoyo que les podamos brindar para lograr sus sueños.
texts.en:
Sr. Elvis A. T. lives with his wife in the home of his in-laws, which is in the village of Santa Dominguita. They do not have any children at the moment, but his wife is pregnant. Elvis has a small plot of land on which he is painstakingly building his house after saving some of his earnings from his job. He works as a factory worker for an agricultural business in the area. His wife was working, but she decided to stop in order to minimize any risk related to her pregnancy. The in-laws help them with the expenses because they are still young workers.

Elvis says his greatest dream is to finish the construction of his house into which he invested much of his savings. He does not have any current debts with any other financial institution. The A. family is grateful for the support to enable them to fulfill their dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finish construction of a house
